result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both OWI (5th or 6th) [Modifiers: Penalty - Operating While under the Influence (5th+ Offense)] and Operating w/ PAC (5th or 6th) [Modifiers: Penalty - Operating While under the Influence (5th+ Offense)]. The defendant was found guilty of OWI (5th or 6th) [Modifiers: Penalty - Operating While under the Influence (5th+ Offense)] and the other charge, Operating w/ PAC (5th or 6th) [Modifiers: Penalty - Operating While under the Influence (5th+ Offense)] was dismissed by the court.

  • Jerome John Houston was found guilty of OWI (5th or 6th) [Modifiers: Penalty - Operating While under the Influence (5th+ Offense)], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Consecutive to: To any other sentence.
and comply with any treatment recommended.

02:32 PM Defendant Jerome John Houston in court, in custody with attorney Amanda K. Riek.  Jordan Lippert appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Rights/Elements. Defendant pled no contest to Ct. 1. Court found guilty. Judgment was entered. Ct. 2 dismissed. Court sentenced the defendant to 4.5 years in prison, consecutive to any other, 2 years initial confinement and 2.5 years extended supervision. Conditions of extended supervision include: $2706.00 fines/costs. $65.00 blood draw fee, 36 mo. DL revocation and 36 mo. IID, AODA and comply with any treatment recommended, submit DNA sample, maintain absolute sobriety. Any bond on hand will be applied towards fine/costs. Defendant is not eligible for the challenge abuse program. Is eligible for the substance abuse program. 180 days credit. 2:51 PM
